conclusion: Consider forces acting on the charged ball under the influence of an electric field.
Ball experiences electric force accelerating in the direction of the electric field and gravitational force accelerating downward.
Identify forces: electric force acts in the direction of the electric field, gravitational force acts downward.
Use equation of motion: \( m \cdot \frac{d^2v}{dt^2} = F_{\text{elec}} - mg \cdot \sin(\theta) \).
Calculate electric potential energy: \( U_{\text{elec}} = \frac{1}{2} m \cdot v^2 \).
Calculate gravitational potential energy: \( U_{\text{grav}} = m \cdot g \cdot \sin(\theta) \).
Determine difference in potential energy: \( \Delta U = U_{\text{elec}} - U_{\text{grav}} = \frac{1}{2} m \cdot v^2 - m \cdot g \cdot \sin(\theta) \).
Substitute given values: \( v_0 = v \), \( g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2 \), \( \sin(\theta) = \theta \).
Calculate difference in potential energy: \( \Delta U = \frac{1}{2} m \cdot v^2 - m \cdot 9.8 \cdot \theta \).
Since \( v_0 = v \), initial velocity \( v_0 \) equals final velocity \( v \).
Electric potential energy at the highest point is less than at point \( O \).
Difference in electric potential energy: \( \Delta U = \frac{1}{2} m \cdot v^2 - m \cdot 9.8 \cdot \theta \).
Since \( \theta \) is the angle between the electric field and the velocity, difference in potential energy is \( \Delta U = \frac{1}{2} m \cdot v^2 - m \cdot 9.8 \cdot \theta \).
Final answer: \( \Delta U = \frac{1}{2} m \cdot v^2 - m \cdot 9.8 \cdot \theta \).
